page.title: 12DRYING PEATS
page.content: Sometimes the thrower can't put all the peats on the spread and then he has to build a wall with the blocks. This wall is called "the bar" and there have to be large air holes in it so that the peats can dry. {STORROWING PEATS:} Three weeks after cutting the peats are ready to be storrowed - that is placed on end in little wigwam like piles so that the air can circulate freely round them. In a wet year those piles sometimes have to be taken down and built up again, outside in. This is known as "astorrowing" and no one does it if they can help it. After another three weeks the peats should be ready to come home.
